definitions.definition: to catch a person or an animal and keep them as a prisoner or shut them in a space that they cannot escape from

examples.text: Allied troops captured over 300 enemy soldiers.
The animals are captured in nets and sold to local zoos.

definitions.definition: to take control of a place, building, etc. using force
to succeed in getting control or possession of something that other people are also trying to get

examples.text: The company has captured 90 per cent of the market.
He captured the world championship title in 2018.

definitions.definition: to make somebody interested in something

examples.text: The project has **captured the imagination **of the local public.
Her story captured the attention of Hollywood.

definitions.definition: to succeed in accurately expressing a feeling, an atmosphere, etc. in a picture, piece of writing, film, etc.

examples.text: Her photos **capture the essence** of her subjects.
The song **captures the spirit** of those times.
They have **captured a moment** in people's lives.
That description captures perfectly the feeling of being invisible.
The article captured the mood of the nation.
The exhibition on India fails to capture the great diversity of this fascinating country.

definitions.definition: to photograph, film, record, paint, etc. somebody/something

examples.text: The photographer's camera **captures images** of extreme beauty.
The attack was captured on film by security cameras.

definitions.definition: to put something into a computer in a form it can use

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent. (as a noun): from French, from Latin captura, from capt- ‘seized, taken’, from the verb capere.
